CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Flash Newspicture Magazine, "Christmas Number" 1938, pg. 18, reads: "It's fair weather when hometowners get together."  Accompanying article reads: "Maxine Sullivan Comes Home to Smoketown.  Hometown girl, Maxine Sullivan makes good and frolics with her old hometown friends of Homestead [Homestead], Pa., who knew her as just petite Maxine of the neighborhood crowd, who now has ascended to the top strata of those on her line.  Maxine has taken her success with astounding modesty.  Press notices described little 90 pound Maxine as a Negro singer with an Irish name who sings Scottish songs like nobody's business.  Loch Lomand, was the Scottish ballad sung by Mrs. Maxine Sullivan Kirby that caused the nation to sit up quickly and listen."
TitMainTitle: Women and men, including George Gaines, Rufus "Sonnyman" Jackson, and Maxine Sullivan gathered in living room of Jackson home, for party in honor of Sullivan, Homestead
